text: I think we need to start with Hell Hound
The dog bit
perfect
I think I need to start this off by saying
there was a time, that I did not like Bill Burr at all
I can remember seeing a half hour special he did when I was...
maybe in High School
a lot of race related humor and I remember it turning me off
I see
and I kind of wrote him off
but
taking the ‘enlightened’ route
I just haven’t seen the light yet
the Let It Go album turned it around for me
and this is from that album, yes?
yes
this seems like a good starting place, because relative to the other Bill Burr I’ve heard, it’s tame, but still his voice
see, I don’t think of it as tame
I think it’s a summation of his voice
He is a lot of things:
gruff, insenistive
I think a lot of people put him in that “guy’s guy” category
I think he puts himself there
like an Adam Carolla, Nick DiPaolo
sure
I’ll give you that
but what we start to see in Hell Hound
he is willing to admit his flaws and laugh at them
well this bit is interesting, because I think the best thing about it is the turn
exactly
and
he has a soft spot
his admission that he does actually love the dog
Burr is not screaming “I am right, you’re an idiot if you disagree"
no
but he is also not saying “turns out I was wrong about the dog, those things I said about my girlfriend and pit bulls in general were pretty unfair, huh!"
I guess what’s impressive about the bit is that he plays both sides of the coin
And he adds a twist
which I would argue
is a lot of what a joke is
getting laughs for a ditzy impression of his girlfriend, and for insinuating that the dog is likely to try and attack him
you think one thing is happening
and the humor is when something else happens
well that’s the thing though,  it didn’t make me laugh
it’s a cute story, and I think a pretty good description of why dogs are great
See, the turn makes me laugh
I laughed a lot the first time
but i still laugh when I listen again
The line that really gets me
is that he turns so hard, that he’s now upset that one day the dog will die
I dunno, doesn’t do it for me
One major thing, that I think may separate you and me here
I think I have some of that built in “men shouldn’t cry” thing
It’s not a genuine belief, but it’s a feeling I still have
Dare I say.. you have none of that?
I wish
I definitely felt that way for most of my adolescence
and now I know it’s preposterous, but knowing that doesn’t undo a decade of programming
by which I mean: I almost never cry
and I think it would be healthier if I did
See, I was thinking you can’t relate
although I’ve started to get choked up at the end of episodes of The Next Generation
The core of what is funny to me about Bill Burr’s point of view: He was raised one way, he has that point of view, but often that is wrong and he can laugh at that and change
that sounds beautiful when you say it
He’s not just stupid sitcom dad
but I don’t know if that’s what’s coming across
He may have some ideas in common with stupid sitcom dad
but he does seem genuinely interested in questioning
which is a lot of what comedy is
Maybe this is time to bring in the podcast: the one with him and his wife
I mean the number one reason I don’t have a dog is that I am afraid of how sad I will be when it dies
let’s finish the dog thing first, the podcast is the silver bullet here
ok
A lot of laughing is relating
I relate hard on the worrying about something dying one day
as an over thinker, I’ve already run through the whole story in my head whenever the idea pops into my head that I would love to have a dog
on holy shit would I love to have a dog
I’m scared that I would love it a little too much, pour my entire self into it
and in ten years, if it died and I was in a committed relationship and had kids or something, I would be devastated
but in ten years, if it died and I was lonely otherwise, or had lost some friends, or felt like I was missing out on love for whatever reason, I would be completely destroyed
That idea alone is kind of funny
deeply sad
and that’s what runs through my head when I look at a little dog’s face on the SPCA website or whatever
but the absurdity of that overthinking
all of that
yeah, welcome to my brain
not that I dont do it too
but
still
so I guess that turn seemed completely natural to me
well of course it’s horribly upsetting that the dog, the little bundle of unadulterated, unfiltered love, is going to die first
natural coming from him?
natural for any person
interesting
I think a major part of this
hard for me to understand people who don’t think about every possible permutation of something
even though I know they don't
you kind of have to be surprised.. that he isn’t a jerk at times?
Are you just assuming the best in all people all the time?
I don’t think that’s it
You can’t be surprised at a good thought from a character who is projecting the opposite?
Alright
I’m pretty optimistic, but I also really value cynicism
Hey, you and Burr
and I used to really have an affection for the “telling it like it is” guy who everyone thinks is a jerk
you used to be that guy
based on your stories...
that’s where I was going with it
I’ll let you finish then
that was me for a long time, and to some people may still be
so of course I have empathy for it, or had I should say
the older I get the more I feel like “telling it like it is” guy is just insensitive guy or ignorant guy
partially because I know so intimately, so painfully, that I was insensitive and ignorant
Sometimes I think of it as “nothing is sacred” guy
and I think that’s important for a comedian
I can’t think of too many comedians I love
that had a lot of fear
or were abiding by society
yeah I’m all for nothing being sacred
I feel like nothing good ever comes from making something off limits
Agreed
but that doesn’t mean that every criticism someone decides to levy is brilliant and iconoclastic
of course not
it can still just be stupid, or needlessly hurtful
but that being a value can be helpful
and not necessarily easy
really easy to say
but not live
and it seems like lots of people don’t know the difference
I assume you watched the Steve Jobs bit
yeah
That’s one of my favorite “nothing is sacred” bits of his
and there it’s not Steve Jobs people are holding sacred
it’s death
oh I’m not sure I agree with that
it’s a little bit of both
asking “What did he do?"
upset a lot of people, beyond just the fact that he was dead
well I would have liked to answer “there are lots of books you can read to answer that question for yourself, Bill”
and I hate you for somehow getting me to defend Steve Jobs, who I do think is remember by many with an overly rosy hue
Oh great
but I think that bit falls completely on its face if he was still alive
“What does he do?” is not funny
it’s not Steve Jobs who is sacred, he was maligned by all sorts of people and media all the time when he was alive
its death that’s sacred.
I agree the bit doesn’t work if he is alive
but it’s a combination of Steve Jobs and death
it’s not just death
and I’m all about taking the sacredness out of death
and this bit was like the Hell Hound one for me
it was _ok_, but the premise is still based on his ignorance
really knowing nothing about what Steve Jobs did
or about the actual characteristics of pit bulls
Not that I think you’re trying to rewrite a joke here
but he does have to play the audience member too
even if he knows, he has to assume the knowledge of the audience
whether he’s hamming it up for the bit or not, I just don’t find it funny
there is so much celebration of ignorance in our culture
Is it a celebration of ignorance?
Or pointing out that this guy doesn’t hold up in our minds that way we all just assume?
The question “What did he do?” makes you ask yourself that
I had lots of answers!
comedy isn’t two way
if you’re not coming up with the answers that hold up to perceived greatness
but I guess if you’re someone that always just read the headlines in the paper
It’s starting to crumble
and the joke starts to work
and never actually thought about Steve Jobs, the simple prompt to actually think might be funny to you
maybe that’s what bothers me
You are a rare bird in that you’ve thought about Steve Jobs way more than most
definitely
but you sent me the clip :wink:
I sure did
and I’m being critical here because that’s the whole point of this
Oh, I misunderstood. You should just be telling I’m great and correct.
you are great! which is the only reason it’s fun to have these conversations with you
haha
anyway, sorry
I’m relistening to the Steve Jobs thing
It’s a challenge, I can explain what I see the value of the bit to be
and why I laugh at it
if I remember, one line got me pretty good
but I can’t make someone else laugh
oh I remember
him calling a pear a pretentious fruit
that’s a great line
Did the advertising angle make you laugh?
the thing that is interesting to me is trying to figure out why I’m not laughing
because obviously most people are
Actually, now that I’m thinking about more reasons I’m laughing
I think because I think about it so much
I’m not here to argue that Bill Burr is objectively unfunny, I’ve heard from enough comedians on podcasts that he’s one of the greats, and they know a lot more about comedy than I do
I love seeing a guy not in our industry
point out that maybe he was a pretentious dick walking around the office
and I’m say “Yes, I thought that too!"
he was, I believe that’s confirmed
I’m not having the normal audience member reaction
but I’m thinking this was inside baseball, maybe not so much
(I also smiled when he said that old iPhone chargers were choking out octopusses)
I mean I think you’re definitely going to be in the majority on this, and I’m going to come off as some pretentious wang
but the idea of doing a comedy bit centered around how I don’t understand why some people like someone, making cheap jokes about him people can relate to, just isn’t funny to me
Well he does understand some about him
I feel like it’s like a 7th grade level of humor
He uses the Chinese factory nets as an example
I don’t think we can assume a 7th grade level of knowledge
but a knowledge the general public might have, maybe more so
there is no way for this not to come off arrogant sounding
arrogant or ignorant?
but I do recognize that a big part of humor is taking something familiar to the listener and exposing a new perspective on it
and in both of our first examples, Burr is not treading any new ground for me
who in our industry doesn’t go through a phase where they wonder if Steve Jobs is an overrated blowhard?
Oh, I think a lot of people
who gets a dog without contemplating the fact that it is going to die well before you?
The key is that people probably have that thought
and that the world is unfair and cruel?
but they don’t say it outloud
I would say that’s very similar to Louis CK saying he hates his kids
The reason it works is because it’s relatable but unspoken
If it were TOTALLY new ground
maybe the reason it works for me is that I don’t have kids
we wouldnt relate and laugh
totally new ground usually upsets people at first
and then maybe we think it’s funny in hindsight
maybe what I don’t like about Burr is it seems like he and I would not get along
like, if we were in a bar, and he asked “what did Steve Jobs do?”, I would start answering and he would probably tell me to suck a dick before I got a single thought out
or at least, his on stage persona would
can’t pretend to know the actual person
new information does not seem welcome in the Burriverse
Do you think that’s really true?
He comes around a lot
he makes it seem as if he only comes around when he figures it out for himself, not from listening to others
which I think is evidenced by his portrayal of his girlfriend in Hell Hound
So then he’s just like every person alive
hah
who may have actually just known very well that he would love a dog, and that pit bulls were loyal
I will admit that to be true about myself very often
but she doesn’t get the generosity of hindsight, only he does
There are not many times I can remember admitting I was was wrong on the spot
well yeah, I’m stubborn too
but this is not on the spot!
No
this is a practiced bit, and he chose to portray her this way
so I’m saying I’m similar
either because he believes it to a degree, or he knows it will get laughs
and I’m not too keen on either one
I do think the girl voice is a cheap laugh
Bill Burr does the girl voice
Jim Gaffigan does the audience voice
Louis CK does the gay voice
pretty standard cheap laugh stuff
are “pit bulls are violent” and “the new iphone doesn’t work with the old charger” not cheap laughs?
god, I hate that dumb ass voice that Louis does
I think the portrayal of the pit bull is fresh
There’s one line in there that really makes me laugh
one sec
Burr feels like a long chain of cheap laughs, strung together by a well practiced stage presence and a lot of charisma
Pitbull mixed with another pitbull makes me laugh a lot
also, showing his name on the phone bill
always laugh out loud
ok that one is great
he has his moments
I don’t think the old charger wrapped around an Octopus is cheap either
He might start with a universal thing
and fine fresh takes and great angles on it
Some of my favorite comedy is taking a seemingly boring premise
and just milking it until there’s nothing left
not that I think the pitbull is that specifically
but I don’t think that’s cheap at all
we should get to the podcast
This is not an example of repeating every old airplane food joke
because I think that’s going to crack this open
Sure
Let’s get there
so first of all, I want to point out that his wife demonstrates the exact kind of listening that Burr has not in anything I’ve seen
she defends her position, and when Bill makes a point that she hadn’t thought of, she gives him credit right then and there
I woud have to assume this is why they can stay married
I am sure Burr is really stubborn
he on the other hand spends half the time complaining that she’s interrupting, even though they each speak for roughly the same amount of time in the clip
and more importantly for me doesn’t really address some of her harder questions
namely, why it should be her duty to educate ignorant people
but he has something interesting to say here
and I think it’s pretty clear that it’s at the root of a lot of his comedy
you could even argue that he’s an incredibly liberal, progressive, informed guy who is intentionally playing with stereotypes in his work because he believes it’s the best way to address these issues
I was hoping you’d get here
I think both him and his wife find their stubborn moments
(if that is his strategy I would love to see some even anecdotal evidence that it works)
he doesn’t address her question and she doesn’t address his late naswer
huh? his late answer?
or his point
that how is this guy supposed to learn
if we just shame him?
well on that point
I think his assumption that if you lose your livelihood because of saying something insensitive you’re guaranteed to just dig in deeper is unfounded
he seems VERY confident that people aren’t going to re-evaluate their views after a public backlash, but I’m not convinced
I think the more important bit, which is kind of glossed over
is that the organizations and companies firing these people don’t have their best interests at heart
I don’t think it’s unfair to say that shame may just be creating bitterness
you can debate all day the best way to reform someone like that, and it probably varies from person to person, but I’m certain these brands are only trying to save face
I’m sure of that too
They’d do the opposite if they made money that way
which seems like a bigger issue than which particular approach is most likely to garner some thoughtfulness
My take away was that he took a very Andy approach to his answer
oh?
I think you’re much more on the side of wanting to talk to an ignorant person
oh yeah for sure
which is clearly his take
that whole podcast clip had me very conflicted
because yes, I think we should do a better job talking about these things
He’s less interested in if the guy is an idiot
which is a very easy way to dismiss him
It is a stupid and offensive question he asks
and I definitely don’t think just tagging certain words or viewpoints as unacceptable is productive
It probably seems exhausting to answer because you assume to know the person asking
you mean the actual question, about the daughter or the gay son?
yes
I make a lot of assumptions about the person asking that question
see there I think he needs to listen to his fucking wife
1. He is ignorant
2. He is just trying to get a cheap laugh himself
but instead of engaging with the guy, making it a teachable moment, which he LITERALLY WAS JUST SAYING IS WHAT WE SHOULD DO
Listen to his wife that this guy is a lost cause?
no
listen to his wife about why the guy is wrong, and what information he needs
instead Burr launches into some seriously fucked up patriarchal bullshit about how men getting laid is a sign of skill and women don’t have to try so they shouldn’t be celebrated for it
which honestly is disgusting to me
I don’t doubt that in his world that is the case, but it doesn’t make it right
we shouldn’t be celebrating men for treating women and sex like some prize to compete for and win
Oh yes, I’m with you on that
and it’s PREPOSTEROUS for him to make any assumptions about what it’s like to navigate sexual politics as a woman
I’m not interested in defending that
but this is my whole thing
That he has some misguided views?
this points to him not being the liberal, progressive person we want him to be, who is using a language to talk to people about real issues
I think this points to him not fitting exactly who we want him to be
it points to him being some guy with some messed up views who has gotten good at getting laughs out of them
which I just frankly have no interest in
I see it: Funny first
some messed up views second
well the “can someone make great art and have personal issues” is a different conversation
for me, they’re not first and second because they’re all twisted together
I think that’s what this comes down to though
I think that’s why you can’t like him
I can’t like him because the things that he thinks are jokes are perfect examples to me of latent, seemingly lovable chauvinism
he wraps it up and sells it really well, but ultimately I think he’s part of the problem
and yes, perhaps part of me is that I can’t turn that part of me off
there is no enjoying it outside of that perspective, because all the humor is lost completely for me
The “wraps ip up and sells it well” could just be called being a great comic
absolutely
and actually, the big part for me
he’s great at what he does
I don’t think he’s part of the problem. I think he has some views that suck.
But I also think he’s trying in general
We didn’t bring up the Philly show
lets
I got some laughs out of that one, and it is a remarkable achievement
It’s both cringeworthy and amazing
well some of it was really brilliant
honestly
there are some just world class burns
calling Philly a shitty “one-bridge” town
It’s the most amazing turn around of an audience I’ve ever seen
and the burns are great
but also some interesting observational stuff, like how the city has decided to champion a fictional boxer over a real one
I would love to see 10 minutes on that
And the Joe Frazier twist
but these bright spots are floating in a sea of boring, predictable garbage
if you took out all the times he told the audience to suck a dick, the clip would be half as long
Yes
He’s winging it, there’s a lot of filler
and yes, I’ll be that jerk that just points out that the very idea that “suck a dick” is an insult, implies that gay men and straight women are lowly
He also say Fag a lot
that sucks too
don’t need to point out why that’s bad
honestly, I don’t get as upset about words
it’s obviously cheap and shitty
but it’s more obvious, so it bothers me less
huh
I guess I feel less like some of his ideas are slowly seeping into people with things like saying “fag"
It’s clear he knows the audeince
my guess is that more people just know that’s homophobic
I think the insult of “suck a dick” is a lot more insidious
it’s sneaky, but he is affirming straight men’s dominance
and everyone else’s subservience
and I don’t think people realize that. I think they come away having strengthened the idea in their heads that sucking a dick is a bad thing
I agree with those things
and he does say it a lot as he works his way into laughs
yeah, this isn’t a written bit
Of coruse not
This is a rant
that ends up being comedic
he’s floating on a sea of “suck a dick, motherfuckers"
while he thinks of the next thing to say
and it is truly remarkable in that sense
He’s genuinely upset that the audience has been so disrespectful
And those are his “ums"
but when you compare this to something like Bernie Mac’s 6 minutes at the Apollo
when the audience was also notoriously harsh
“I ain’t scared of you motherfuckers"
Bernie is brilliant, through and through
is his “suck a dick"
yeah
but “I ain’t scared of you” is 1000 times better
and funnier
and doesn’t denigrate others to boot
Do you think that would have worked the same way though?
Those are two very different audiences
I don’t know
Apollo audiecnes are known for trying to intimidate
The Philly audience just hated everything
but I know that everything about Burr reeks of privilege to me. he deserves to be there, and if you don’t think so you should suck his dick
They are addressing different things
he’s even getting paid to tell you so, as he reminds us
Bernie is building himself up. He is asserting himself, but not in such a presumptuous way
Um
and inbetween his direct rebuffs of the audience, he actually does some of his material
He opens by telling the audience how big his dick is
oh come on Matt
Are you remembering with rosy glasses?
this is just like Kendick’s Backseat Freestyle
that assertion of dominance means something much different coming from a black man in America than it does from a white man
This is true
our culture has endlessly disenfranchised and disadvantaged black men
but I think no matter who you are
when you have a microphone, and you are one person on a stage
and rap music, and Bernie talking about how good he is at sex, and every other example of machismo  is a triumph over an oppressive regime
you have to establish dominace
If you’ve ever seen a comedian walk on a stage and show weakness, no matter who you are
It’s going to go poorly
Burr is indignant, Mac is assertive
Do you think Burr is unjustified?
mmmm
I don’t think it’s about justification? I just don’t think it’s funny.
I will say this about the difference between those sets
a pissed off white guy telling a stadium full of people to suck his dick isn’t funny to me
I agree that Burr is indignant, Mac is assertive
I love both for similar reasons
Burr’s digs make me laugh a lot
Mac’s material doesn’t really
I’ll agree that I don’t find Bernie’s set as funny as the little deal he struck with the DJ and the things inbetween
and as I said, Burr got a few smiles out of me with his characterizations of philadelphia, which is the city I grew up closest to
but Bernie is not talking to your or I in that set
Agreed
we are miles from the audience in the apollo that night
but I’m just a few beers shy of being exactly the person Burr has in his scope that night, at least on paper
and even given all that advantage, I still don’t find the whole thing very funny, save for a few moments
and the whole thing drips of white male supremacy in a way that really gets to me
not in a way that Burr can avoid, mind you
well, I guess he could try to be more thoughtful
He is an aggressive white man
but it’s not his fault that he finds these things funny
it’s a reflection of the culture he was raised in
I dont think he could be a thoughtful guy on stage and make ti work
it’s that culture I’m disappointed in, not Burr himself
He can be an aggressive guy that lives in this culture and surprises you though
sidebar: I keep imagining I’m talking about Aaron Burr
and it’s making me laugh
yes, he can be
and if he were to go a step further, I think it might really have an impact on me
I think the key to the Philly show
The Hell Hound bit should be judged by how it made you laugh
if he recognized how fragile masculinity is
the Philly show should be judged by how the audience reacted
A live show really should be judged by who was in the audience
the Philly thing is a remarkable accomplishment for sure
an album is different
I just don’t think it’s great comedy
either or the live show?
and to your point, I don’t think Bernie Mac’s Apollo set is great comedy either necessarily
but his assertiveness is affirming and beautiful to me, and Burr’s is the opposite
I think both Apollo and Philly prove
that both men are great at what they do
They are both great comics, in what I know a comic to be
on a level not many reach
on how much the material of either may make you laugh
is where we will always be split
_Fin_
hah
gosh how many words do you think that was?
a lot
would anyone ever read that?
I don’t know! but I’m kind of excited to find out
alright!
fwiw, I think I would have laughed my ass off at Bill Burr in high school or early college
which I don’t mean as some enlightened insult
but I do get it, I just can’t get over it
If i didn’t know you and you said that on twitter
I’d be mad but I know, hah
the “Steve Jobs walks by eating some pretentious fruit, like a pear"
and showing the pitbull his name on the phone bill
these are great jokes!
I don’t think it’s a coincidence that the great ones are also the ones that are least offensive
Joe Frazier should be eternalized in a statue!
it’s SO SILLY to have a statue of a fictional boxer
That statue is still in transit by the way
when I was a kid I assumed he was real because WHY WOULD YOU HAVE A STATUE OF A FICTIONAL CHARACTER
haha
I thought the Rocky movies were a dramatization of real events
